snippet: Forced by the harsh realities of the real estate market, lenders are increasingly likely to allow defaulting owners to remain in their homes.
abstract: Mortgage lenders, forced by the harsh realities of the real estate market, are increasingly likely to allow defaulting owners to remain in their homes; change in attitude and strategy is helping to buoy some neighborhoods while further slowing the nation's foreclosure process; more than 644,458 properties were lingering in bank ownership at the end of January, but 710,725 more are in the foreclosure pipeline.
lead_paragraph: Forced by the harsh realities of the real estate market, lenders are increasingly likely to allow defaulting owners to remain in their homes.

headline.main: When Living in Limbo Avoids Living on the Street
